* The invention is particularly advantageous for gas turbine blades.  
	* * It simplifies blade production, reduces centrifugal-force stresses, and allows for easier adjustments to cooling systems.  
	* * Inserts can be introduced through the blade root or tip, with secure seating to prevent bulging under centrifugal forces.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a system for controlling fuel delivery in vehicles, allowing seamless switching between automatic and manual control.  
	• Automatic control uses a control unit to process accelerator pedal and throttle valve signals, optimizing vehicle performance.  
	• Manual control engages a clutch, connecting the accelerator pedal directly to the throttle valve for full driver control.  

• The system addresses deficiencies in prior systems, such as lurching or stalling during control transitions.  
	• Switching to manual control occurs only when the throttle valve matches the accelerator pedal position or reaches a predetermined state.  
	• Manual control provides full vehicle operation, unlike prior systems that limit speed during malfunctions.  

• The system integrates with continuously variable transmissions and uses stepper or DC motors for throttle control.  
	• At high transmission ratios, manual control is preferred for startup, while automatic control is used at low ratios for efficiency.  
	• Subroutines and logic sequencers manage motor control and smooth transitions between modes.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention describes a waste fuel burner designed for efficient combustion of particulate-laden gas or waste fuels like wood waste.  
	• The burner operates in two stages: a primary combustion chamber for gasification and partial oxidation, and a secondary combustion chamber for complete combustion.  
	• It uses controlled airflows, including underfire, swirl, and secondary air, to optimize combustion, reduce particulate emissions, and prevent slag formation.  

• Key features include a conical fuel pile, air-cooled flame holder, and pressure isolator to enhance combustion efficiency and particulate separation.  
	• The flame holder and pressure isolator prevent particulate from entering the secondary chamber, ensuring cleaner exhaust gases.  
	• The system is self-regulating, with airflows adjusted based on fuel moisture content and combustion chamber temperatures.  

• The burner offers advantages such as fast response times, low clinker formation, and compatibility with high-moisture fuels.  
	• It can handle fuels with up to 70% moisture content and operates with minimal excess air, improving energy efficiency.  
	• The design allows for easy integration with boilers or industrial processes, reducing maintenance and extending refractory lining life.  
</summary>

<summary>
* Field of the Invention  
	* The invention pertains to air conditioning, specifically evaporative refrigeration.  
	* It focuses on cooling air without increasing its moisture content.  

* Background and Summary  
	* Evaporative coolers use the temperature difference between dry and wet bulb temperatures for cooling.  
	* The invention improves efficiency by separating evaporating water from useful air and recirculating working air from the enclosure.  

* Key Features and Operation  
	* A heat exchanger separates dry and wet sides, with water evaporating on the wet side and useful air cooled on the dry side.  
	* Working air is drawn from the enclosure, enhancing cooling efficiency by leveraging lower wet bulb temperatures.  

* Hybrid System and Efficiency Enhancements  
	* A hybrid system combines evaporative cooling with a vapor compression refrigeration unit for dehumidification.  
	* The system reduces energy consumption by pre-cooling condenser coils with exhaust air from the wet side.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* Fluid Pump Design:  
	* The fluid pump comprises multiple pump heads arranged in series, each with an impeller and housing to move fluid through conduits.  
	* The pump heads are connected to allow fluid flow from one to the next, with a drive structure commonly driving all impellers.  

* Modular and Series Configuration:  
	* The pump can include two, three, or more pump heads in series, with each head contributing to increased operating pressure.  
	* Pump heads are modular, allowing for easy repair or addition of more heads to adjust performance.  

* Drive Structure and Impellers:  
	* A single drive structure, such as a drive shaft, connects and drives all impellers, ensuring synchronized operation.  
	* Impellers are designed with arcuate vanes to efficiently move fluid tangentially through the conduits.  

* Combiner and Fluid Flow:  
	* Each pump head includes a combiner to merge fluid from multiple conduits into a single flow before passing to the next head.  
	* The combiner ensures fluid flows smoothly between pump heads while protecting the drive structure from fluid exposure.  

* Pump Assembly and Applications:  
	* The pump can be mounted on various support structures, such as a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer, for use in fluid reservoirs.  
	* Applications include pumping liquid manure from reservoirs, with optional agitator nozzles to mix the fluid in the reservoir.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to an engine compression release brake system for engines with fewer brakes than cylinders.  
	• It addresses the inefficiency of traditional systems by reducing excess components.  
	• The system includes brakes for only a portion of the engine cylinders, improving robustness.  
	• A method is provided for operating the brakes on selected cylinders during engine braking.  

• The system uses hydraulic and mechanical components to control exhaust valves for braking.  
	• High-pressure oil and solenoids are used to actuate the brakes during the compression stroke.  
	• The system allows modularity, enabling customization of braking horsepower based on application needs.  
	• The design can be modified for different engine configurations and valve orientations.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a mounting link between an engine and an auxiliary gearbox, designed to withstand extreme loads like blade-off events.  
	• The link assembly includes a male link and a female link that form a radial interface to dampen relative motion.  
	• A releasable pin selectively retains the male and female links, designed to shear under extreme loads.  
	• The system prevents damage to the gearbox and attached peripherals while maintaining connection to the engine.  

• The gearbox assembly includes a gearbox and a link assembly to couple it to the engine.  
	• The link assembly allows translation between the male and female links after the pin shears.  
	• The radial interface provides coulomb damping to dissipate energy during relative motion.  
	• The system avoids overconstraint, ensuring independent degrees of freedom for the gearbox.  

• The mounting link includes a female link with a cavity to receive the male link.  
	• The female link has a mounting end for attachment to the engine or gearbox.  
	• The male link has a mounting end for attachment to the opposite component.  
	• The pin passes through aligned holes in both links to retain them until sheared.  

• The pin acts as a fusible link, designed to shear at a predefined load magnitude.  
	• The pin is strong enough to withstand routine shocks but breaks under extreme loads like blade-off events.  
	• The shear plane is predefined to ensure controlled failure.  
	• The pin can be replaced during maintenance after shearing.  

• The radial interface between the male and female links provides coulomb damping.  
	• Damping is determined by the coefficient of friction, geometry, and contact areas.  
	• Materials are selected to achieve the desired damping force.  
	• The damping force may be greater or less than the force required to shear the pin.  

• A snap ring limits the relative travel of the male link within the female link.  
	• The snap ring prevents the mounting link from separating after the pin shears.  
	• It retains the male link at the end of its travel range.  
	• This ensures the gearbox remains connected to the engine even after extreme shocks.  

• The system reduces the need for heavy reinforcement of linkages and peripherals.  
	• It avoids the impracticality of designing all components to survive extreme loads.  
	• The design minimizes weight and material requirements.  
	• Maintenance includes replacing

<summary>  
* The invention introduces a point cap system and balance pin for archery arrows, designed to improve arrow balance and reduce stress on arrow shafts.  
	* The point cap system includes an externally threaded end for attaching arrow points, reducing internal stress on the shaft and preventing dirt entry.  
* The balance pin allows for adjustable weight to achieve perfect arrow balance and can be trimmed to desired lengths.  
	* The balance pin is made of a heavy, soft metal like brass and can be bonded to the interior of arrow points or point caps.  
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is a cost-effective, electronically controlled pyrotechnic simulator for small arms training.
    • It simulates the sound and flash of small arms fire without modifying the weapon.
    • It uses a low-cost plastic expendable housing with a metal/oxidizer pyrotechnic and an electrical ignition system.
    • The expendable contains multiple rounds and is installed in a firing unit inserted into the weapon via the magazine breech.
    • It produces sound and flash by igniting the pyrotechnic in a confined space and venting combustion through the weapon's ejection port.

• The simulator includes an electrical control circuit for automatic and semi-automatic fire.
    • The circuit interfaces with the weapon's trigger and bolt for realistic simulation.
    • It uses CMOS ICs, SCRs, diodes, capacitors, resistors, and switches for functionality.
    • The bolt interface ensures safety by preventing firing when the weapon bolt is open or the unit is removed.

• The expendable is designed for low-cost, automated fabrication.
    • It consists of 30 cups, each containing a pyrotechnic charge and a bridge wire for ignition.
    • The charges are sealed with a plastic sealant and encased in a plastic casing.
    • The combustion of the charge produces pressure, which ruptures the sealant and vents through the weapon's ejection port, simulating small arms fire.

• The simulator enhances realism by resembling the M16 magazine clip.
    • It includes a reusable housing with an exhaust port for venting gases.
    • The housing contains a battery compartment, control circuitry, and the expendable.
    • A selector switch and trigger overlay are mounted on the housing for user control.

• The invention is designed for use with the M16 rifle and MILES unit.
    • It provides realistic training conditions without the cost and maintenance of blanks.
    • The electrical ignition system ensures reliability and low maintenance.
    • The simulator is reusable, with only the expendable needing replacement after use.
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to an air intake device for internal combustion engines, designed to improve engine performance and reduce noise.  
	• It includes a tank connected to the intake passage via two pipes with different cross-sectional areas, and a valve controlled by engine operating conditions.  
• The device optimizes volumetric efficiency and noise reduction through a resonator effect.  
	• A narrow pipe (pipe 6) connected to the tank acts as a resonator, absorbing noise while minimally affecting dynamic efficiency.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a two-part mounting bracket for attaching speakers or equipment to poles, walls, or other surfaces.  
    • It simplifies installation by allowing one person to mount heavy objects without needing to hold the object and tighten hardware simultaneously.  

• The bracket assembly consists of a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket.  
    • The stationary bracket is attached to the mounting surface, while the adjustable bracket is attached to the object, enabling easy directional adjustment.  

• The system uses tapered springs, hooks, and tabs for temporary alignment and locking.  
    • Final adjustments are made using screws, and the assembly is resistant to weather, wind, and vibration, with stainless steel components preferred.  

• For pole mounting, the system includes pole adapters and a chain with J-hooks and wing nuts for secure attachment.  
    • The chain provides 360-degree horizontal adjustment and prevents rotation or slippage without over-tightening.  

• The invention is versatile and suitable for various applications, including loudspeakers, lighting, signage, and monitors.  
    • It reduces installation time and costs by using minimal, robust components and eliminating the need for multiple adapters or additional installers.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a modular burner system for heat-utilizing appliances, designed for efficient and clean combustion.  
	• The burner features a combustion chamber with a fuel holder, air flow paths for primary, secondary, and tertiary combustion, and a shroud for insulation and safety.  
• The system includes interchangeable modular appliances such as cookers, smokers, space heaters, and pyrolyzers.  
	• These appliances can be attached to the burner using manual couplings, enabling versatility and convenience.  
• The burner incorporates features like an ash pan, adjustable air dampers, and pivotable covers for safety and efficiency.  
	• It also supports long-term operation with potential fuel feed mechanisms and includes a pyrolyzer for converting carboniferous materials into usable fuels.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* Background and Challenges of Rotary Engine Cooling  
	* Rotary engines face cooling challenges due to uneven heating, particularly around spark plug areas, leading to thermal distortion and potential structural failures.  
	* The in-line arrangement of spark plugs disrupts coolant flow, causing vapor films and reduced heat extraction, especially in critical hot spots.  

* Proposed Solution: Staggered Spark Plug Boss Configuration  
	* The invention introduces staggered spark plug bosses to improve coolant flow, reduce vapor binding, and enhance heat transfer by up to 44%.  
	* The staggered design allows controlled flow paths, preventing flow shadows and improving temperature uniformity across the combustion surface.  

* Structural and Functional Benefits  
	* The staggered arrangement maintains close in-line spark plug terminals for effective combustion while optimizing coolant flow around the bosses.  
	* Flow diverters and controlled turbulence increase the heat transfer coefficient, reducing thermal stress and improving engine durability.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to minimizing flow disturbances during turbine control valve testing by using valve positions as feedback.  
    * It addresses issues like steam boiler pressure changes and turbine power fluctuations caused by valve closures during testing.  
* The method maintains constant total mass flow through parallel turbine inlet control valves during testing.  
    * It uses valve stem lift data to calculate flow changes and compensates by adjusting the remaining valves' positions.  
* A control circuit is described, incorporating test compensation to minimize flow disturbances.  
    * The circuit uses lookup tables and feedback loops to adjust valve positions dynamically during testing.  
* Simulation results show a 95% reduction in pressure excursions when using the compensation method.  
    * Graphs compare performance with and without the compensation, demonstrating its effectiveness.  
</summary>

<summary>
* Background and Purpose of the Invention:
    * The invention relates to a mixing valve for combining fluids from two sources into a single mixture.
    * Specifically designed for aircraft cleaning, it allows adjustable mixing ratios from 0% to 100% for each fluid.
    * Pressurized cleaning systems are common, but this invention focuses on providing continuous, adjustable control.
    * The goal is to enable multiple users to control cleaning solution strength without disrupting team workflows.

* Technical Description of the Mixing Valve:
    * The valve has two inlets (A and B) and one outlet, with adjustable mixing ratios.
    * It includes a valve body, inlet passages, an outlet passage, and an adjustable valve mechanism.
    * The valve mechanism allows analog control of fluid proportions, ranging from 0% to 100% for each fluid.
    * The system is designed to maintain constant pressure for both fluids during operation.

* Applications and Prior Art:
    * Similar systems are used in household, car wash, and drain cleaning applications.
    * Prior patents (e.g., U.S. Pat. Nos. 4,967,960, 4,773,113, 5,161,753) describe related cleaning systems.
    * The invention improves upon these by offering continuous, adjustable mixing for aircraft cleaning.
    * It addresses the need for a standalone system that allows multiple users to control cleaning solutions independently.

* Valve Components and Assembly:
    * The valve body includes bores, inlet passages, and an outlet passage for fluid flow.
    * A flow-restricting device controls the flow rate of one fluid (e.g., soap solution).
    * The valve mechanism includes a spool valve with cylindrical spools and channels for fluid control.
    * Sealing sleeves and fluid seal rings prevent leakage and commingling of fluids.

* Operation of the Valve System:
    * The valve adjusts fluid proportions by rotating a handle, which aligns or misaligns bores with fluid passages.
    * At one extreme, the outlet delivers 100% water; at the other, 100% soap solution.
    * Intermediate positions provide proportional mixtures, such as 50% water and 50% soap solution.
    * The system prevents backflow using check valves or similar mechanisms.

* Design Features for Pressure Maintenance:
    * Flow-restricting devices and bore sizes reduce fluid flow rates, maintaining constant pressure.
    * The valve design ensures maximum flow only when bores are fully aligned with fluid passages.
    * This reduces

<summary>  
• **Field of the Invention**  
	• The invention relates to gas compression in compressor stations for gas pipelines, especially in permanent frost areas.  
	• It involves compressing gas to a higher pressure, cooling it, and feeding it back into the pipeline at a lower temperature.  
	• The method ensures the gas temperature remains at or below 0°C to prevent ground thawing in frost areas.  
	• An arrangement for carrying out the method is also described.  

• **Background and Challenges**  
	• Natural gas is transported over long distances via pipelines, requiring compressor stations to maintain pressure.  
	• In permanent frost areas, ground thawing due to pipeline heat can cause structural damage.  
	• Cooling the gas to ≤0°C is essential, but conventional cooling methods are costly and inefficient during warmer months.  
	• Re-cooling plants using propane as a coolant pose safety risks and are unused for most of the year.  

• **Objective of the Invention**  
	• To reduce investment costs and operational risks in compressor stations.  
	• To eliminate the need for separate re-cooling plants during warmer months.  
	• To utilize gas expansion for cooling, reducing reliance on external cooling systems.  
	• To improve the efficiency and safety of gas compression and cooling processes.  

• **Method of the Invention**  
	• Gas is compressed to an excess pressure higher than the desired exit pressure.  
	• The compressed gas is cooled via heat exchange to a temperature above the exit temperature.  
	• Further cooling is achieved by expanding the gas to the desired exit pressure.  
	• Expansion can be done via valves or expansion turbines, with the latter recovering energy.  

• **Compressor Station Arrangement**  
	• Includes compressors, heat exchangers, valve-controlled pipelines, and electronic controls.  
	• Compressors operate in stages, with primary and booster compressors for excess pressure.  
	• Expansion turbines recover energy during gas expansion, reducing overall energy consumption.  
	• The system is adaptable for summer and winter operations, with parallel compressor use in winter.  

• **Advantages of the Invention**  
	• Significant reduction in investment costs (40-45% lower than conventional systems).  
	• Elimination of safety risks associated with propane-based re-cooling plants.  
	• Improved energy efficiency through energy recovery in expansion turbines.  
	• Year-round operation with adaptable compressor configurations for seasonal changes.  

• **Operational Example**

<summary>  
• Overview of Cooling Fan Assembly  
    • Electronic components generate heat during operation, requiring cooling mechanisms.  
    • Free convection cooling is insufficient for high-power applications, necessitating forced air cooling.  
    • Cooling fans are a cost-effective solution to maintain acceptable operating temperatures.  
    • Traditional fastening methods for cooling fans increase product costs due to labor and tool requirements.  

• Embodiments of the Cooling Fan Mounting System  
    • The system eliminates traditional fasteners, reducing costs and simplifying installation.  
    • Applicable in industries like automotive, computers, and electronic instrumentation.  
    • The system integrates cooling fans with enclosures using resilient mounting legs.  
    • The design prevents vibrational noise and disengagement during operation.  

• Structural Components of the Cooling Fan Assembly  
    • The assembly includes a motor, fan blade, and motor carrier with mounting legs.  
    • Mounting legs feature resilient leg portions separated by a compression gap.  
    • The panel includes recessed portions with openings for mounting the fan assembly.  
    • Spring members ensure the motor carrier remains securely seated during operation.  

• Installation Process of the Cooling Fan Assembly  
    • The assembly is initially positioned in a load position, with turned-out portions aligned with enlarged openings.  
    • A compressive and rotating force moves the assembly into a partially installed position.  
    • Resilient leg portions transition into intermediate and residual openings during installation.  
    • Spring members remain compressed, securing the assembly and preventing vibrational disengagement.  

• Benefits and Variations of the System  
    • The system reduces installation costs by eliminating traditional fasteners.  
    • It accommodates various motor types, including electric, hydraulic, and pneumatic.  
    • The design allows adjacent components to abut the enclosure exterior without interference.  
    • Alternative spring mechanisms can be used to achieve the same urging function.  
</summary>

<summary>
* Background and Problem Statement  
    * Spacecraft structures use lightweight composites with low damping, leading to high vibration levels.  
    * Vibration can compromise the functionality of instruments, especially those on precision kinematic mounts (KM).  
    * Historical data shows 14% of spacecraft launches (up to 1984) suffered vibration-related failures, with 50% resulting in catastrophic mission loss.  

* Current Efforts and Limitations  
    * Ongoing efforts focus on modifying graphite structures to reduce vibration, but results may be insufficient.  
    * Conventional KM designs lack damping mechanisms, amplifying flight loads to instruments.  
    * Existing KM designs provide minimal damping, making them ineffective in mitigating vibration.  

* Objectives of the Invention  
    * Introduce damping features into kinematic mounts to protect instruments from flight loads.  
    * Provide a passive energy-dissipating mechanism within the KM structure.  
    * Simplify manufacturing by using six identical strut elements and rearranging their configuration for improved performance.  

* Damping Mechanisms  
    * Damping materials are inserted into KM flexure or hinge locations to dissipate vibration energy.  
    * Two preferred damper designs: spherical damper (FIG. 3A) and cylindrical slot damper (FIG. 3B).  
    * Damping materials (e.g., viscoelastic materials) are frequency-dependent, ensuring minimal stiffness during thermal loads.  

* Spherical Damper Design (FIG. 3A)  
    * Comprises two partial shells with a viscoelastic layer in between, bonded to the mount.  
    * Activates during bending, dissipating energy through shear deformation of the viscoelastic layer.  
    * Maintains kinematic mount action by leveraging frequency-dependent properties of the damping material.  

* Cylindrical Slot Damper Design (FIG. 3B)  
    * Uses o-rings or washers made of high-damping viscoelastic material within machined slots.  
    * Dissipates energy through compression/tension of the damping material during vibration.  
    * Achieves up to 10% critical modal damping, significantly reducing vibration response.  

* Mount Configuration and Benefits  
    * Six identical struts simplify manufacturing and reduce costs (FIGS. 5A-5B).  
    * Struts arranged to intersect at the instrument’s center-of-mass, uncoupling suspension modes.  
    * Provides a center-of-gravity mounting system, improving stability and performance.  

* Performance Improvements  
    * Modal damping

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a large oil shear clutch unit for high-power applications, such as aircraft catapult systems.  
    * It addresses challenges like residual drag, cooling, and force distribution in large clutches, reducing residual drag to less than 500 horsepower.  
* The clutch unit features interleaved clutch plates and discs, with separate piston-cylinder mechanisms for each disc segment.  
    * This design ensures uniform force application, minimizes residual drag, and allows hydraulic fluid to act as both a coolant and a retraction mechanism.  
* The clutch discs are segmented for easier replacement and maintenance without full disassembly.  
    * Segmented discs enable the use of standard manufacturing equipment and reduce heat-related wear.  
* The system includes a servo control valve and multi-stage fluid amplifiers for precise pressure and flow control.  
    * This ensures accurate torque profiling based on operational conditions, such as wind, temperature, and aircraft type.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention describes an internal combustion engine system with combustion and expansion cylinders designed to maximize energy efficiency and reduce heat loss.  
	* Combustion cylinders generate exhaust gas, which is further expanded in downstream expansion cylinders to capture additional energy.  
	* Water injection into the expansion cylinders creates steam, driving pistons and cooling exhaust gases, potentially eliminating the need for a radiator.  
* The system incorporates advanced features to optimize performance and reduce emissions.  
	* Catalytic materials are applied to surfaces exposed to exhaust gases to reduce impurities within the engine itself.  
	* Gearing systems synchronize the operation of combustion and expansion cylinders, optimizing mechanical output and reducing back pressure.  
* The invention includes water recovery and cooling systems to enhance sustainability and efficiency.  
	* Water is recovered from exhaust gases and reused for injection, minimizing the need for external water sources.  
	* Heat from combustion cylinders is transferred to expansion cylinders, further improving energy capture and reducing exhaust temperatures.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention addresses challenges in fabricating coated steel plates for automotive parts, focusing on preventing intermetallic areas in welded joints and ensuring corrosion resistance.  
	* It proposes removing a specific portion of the metal alloy layer from the precoat at the plate's periphery before welding to avoid intermetallic formation during heat treatment.  
* The precoat consists of an intermetallic alloy layer and a metal alloy layer, with the metal layer removed by brushing or laser ablation.  
	* The width of the removal area is adjusted to be 20-40% greater than half the weld width to prevent coating transfer into the molten weld area.  
* The method involves welding precoated plates, heat treatment to form an intermetallic alloy compound, and cooling to achieve desired mechanical properties.  
	* The resulting parts exhibit high tensile strength (>1450 MPa), good ductility (≥4% elongation), and excellent corrosion resistance.  
* The invention is particularly useful for automotive safety and structural parts, such as bumpers, door reinforcements, and B-pillars.  
	* It eliminates brittle intermetallic areas in welded joints, ensuring both mechanical performance and corrosion protection.  
</summary>

<summary>
• Overview of the Invention
    • The invention is a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system for remotely controlling mobile energy recovery structures.
    • It optimizes energy extraction from severe weather patterns using algorithms that process weather and sensor data.
    • The system is designed for unmanned operation in hazardous environments, such as offshore tropical storms or hurricanes.
    • It applies to various mobile structures, including sailing vessels, wind turbines, and wave energy conversion systems.

• Key Components and Functionality
    • The system includes GPS, weather satellites, and telecommunications satellites for data collection and communication.
    • It uses Human Machine Interface (HMI) software for remote human interaction and mission-critical navigation planning.
    • The SCADA system integrates weather data from sources like NOAA, NASA, and the National Weather Service.
    • It employs algorithms to optimize energy extraction and navigation based on weather patterns and vessel performance models.

• Mobile Structure Control and Navigation
    • The mobile structure is equipped with sensors and control mechanisms for navigation, such as rudder rotation, sail trim, and turbine gate adjustments.
    • The system uses a Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) for robust control and communication in harsh environments.
    • It includes electromechanical circuits for actuating control mechanisms, such as motors and gears for rudder and sail adjustments.
    • The system can automatically adjust navigation parameters to optimize energy extraction and avoid hazards.

• Communication and Data Processing
    • Data is communicated between the mobile structure and a central service facility via wireless or satellite links.
    • The central service facility aggregates weather data and runs server software for data processing and analysis.
    • The system uses secure communication protocols, such as TCP/IP and IPSec, for data transmission.
    • It employs a Local Area Network (LAN) for internal communication within the central service facility.

• Graphical User Interface (GUI) and Human Interaction
    • The GUI provides visual representations of the mobile structure's position, heading, velocity, and energy extraction status.
    • Human operators can interact with the GUI to manually adjust navigation parameters or override automated controls.
    • The GUI displays weather maps, path analysis, and virtual reality representations of the mobile structure's attitude.
    • Operators can select mission-critical navigation parameters, such as cost and yield weights, through the GUI.

• Applications and Benefits
    • The system enables cost-effective energy extraction from severe weather patterns, reducing risks to human life.
    • It can be applied to various mobile structures, including those extracting energy from

<summary>
* Field of the Invention  
    * The invention relates to a rolling body guide cage made from at least one ring element and guide structures for rolling bodies.  
    * It also includes a method for manufacturing such a rolling body guide cage.  

* Background  
    * DE 1 625 540 A1 discloses a ball bearing cage made of two profiled ring elements welded together.  
    * A disadvantage is the high amount of waste material generated during production.  

* Summary of the Invention  
    * The invention aims to reduce production costs by using flat material ring segments welded together before forming.  
    * This approach significantly reduces cutting waste, especially for cages with an internal diameter over 140 mm.  

* Preferred Embodiments  
    * Flat material ring segments are welded along edge regions with positively engaging joint contours.  
    * The segments are cut as 120° ring segments, allowing efficient material use and requiring only three weld points.  

* Method of Manufacturing  
    * The method involves welding flat material ring segments before forming the axial profiling.  
    * Laser welding or pressure welding is used to create high-strength weld points with minimal distortion.  

* Additional Features  
    * Material beads can be formed near edges to ensure complete weld seam filling.  
    * Ring segments can be axially secured using local material forming techniques.  

* Applications  
    * The invention is suitable for radial and axial bearing cages, including groove and angular ball bearings.  
    * The method allows for overlapping punching and welding steps, improving production efficiency.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* Methods and systems for obtaining and using GPS coordinates to enhance customer service in telecommunications:  
	* A system is described where a service technician uses an input device to access a technician server, which communicates with a GPS system to obtain latitude and longitude coordinates for a customer's service location. These coordinates are stored in databases and used to improve response times and accuracy in locating service locations.  
* Methods and systems for generating travel directions between customer service locations:  
	* A mapping system is integrated with the technician server and GPS system to provide driving directions between multiple customer service locations. The system uses "from" and "to" coordinates to generate and output travel directions, improving efficiency in routing service technicians.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* System for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields:  
	* Utilizes two triaxial magnetic field sensors and three pairs of compensation coils.  
	* Employs a digital control unit (e.g., DSP or FPGA) to process sensor signals and generate control signals for the coils.  
* Virtual sensor simulation and control algorithm:  
	* Combines signals from two real sensors into a virtual sensor signal using a 6×6 matrix (M).  
	* Applies control algorithms (Ω) to modify virtual signals and generate coil control signals via a 6×6 matrix (L).  
* Handling feedback effects in multiple systems:  
	* Introduces a 6×6 feedback matrix (C) to account for cross-coupling between adjacent compensation systems.  
	* Adjusts control signals to mitigate feedback effects, ensuring optimal compensation in multi-system setups.  
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a method for investigating biological samples using CARS microscopy.
    • The method involves generating a resonance signal through coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering by exciting resonance sites in the sample with laser irradiation.

• The method improves upon conventional CARS microscopy by introducing resonance sites via bioorthogonal reactions.
    • Bioorthogonal reactions allow the introduction of resonance sites into samples that do not inherently possess them, enhancing detection capabilities.

• The invention enables the use of small molecules for tagging, which can penetrate deep into tissues without steric hindrance.
    • This is advantageous for three-dimensional imaging in biological samples, such as nerve tissue.

• The method involves coupling intrinsic chemical structures of the sample with reaction partners to create resonance sites.
    • Resonance sites can be part of the reaction partner or generated during the bioorthogonal reaction itself.

• Bioorthogonal reactions used in the method include Diels-Alder reactions, Staudinger ligation, and copper-free click chemistry.
    • These reactions are highly selective and can proceed in living systems without interfering with natural processes.

• The method allows for the tagging of non-resonant background structures, improving reproducibility and quantitative analysis.
    • This is achieved by introducing resonance sites into the background, creating a stable and reproducible signal.

• The invention is particularly useful for species-selective imaging without the need for additional tagging or dyes.
    • It provides molecular structure information with three-dimensional spatial resolution.

• The method can be applied to various biological samples, including animal tissues, plant structures, and processed samples like oils.
    • It is suitable for applications such as purity checking and food chemistry.

• The invention combines the advantages of multi-photon techniques with selective chemical reactions.
    • This allows for deeper tissue penetration and improved image production compared to conventional fluorescent dyes.

• The method involves a two-step process: introducing a bioorthogonal functional group into the sample and then coupling it with a tagging substance.
    • This process ensures that the sample's structure is not negatively affected, maintaining bioactivity.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention provides a system for assessing segmentations in radiation therapy.
    • It compares segmentations from different sources, such as clinicians or software systems.
    • It evaluates the quality of segmentations by identifying missing, extra, and common volume elements.
    • The system outputs a metric indicating the conformance between segmentations.

• The system uses electronic files, such as DICOM-RT files, to define segmentations.
    • These files contain data points describing 3D surfaces of structures in a patient.
    • The system converts these files into volume models for comparison.
    • The comparison is performed on a voxel-by-voxel basis.

• The system provides a graphical display of the comparison results.
    • Common, missing, and extra volume elements are displayed in different colors (e.g., green, blue, red).
    • The display can be superimposed on cross-sectional images of patient tissue.
    • This helps users identify regions of error and improve segmentation skills.

• The system allows for customizable metric methods to evaluate segmentation quality.
    • Metrics can be based on the number of missing and extra volume elements.
    • Distance measures can be used to weight the significance of errors.
    • Users can define their own metric methods using parameters like constant, linear, and exponential functions.

• The system supports training and quality assurance for clinicians and autosegmentation programs.
    • It compares trainee segmentations against a "gold standard" segmentation.
    • It evaluates autosegmentation routines for accuracy and consistency.
    • It can be used to assess new imaging technologies or updated segmentation algorithms.

• The system includes a user interface for loading and comparing segmentation files.
    • Users can select and align segmentation files for comparison.
    • The interface displays common structures and allows for cross-sectional plane selection.
    • It provides tools for correcting spatial offsets between segmentations.

• The system generates quantitative evaluations of segmentation comparisons.
    • It calculates primary, secondary, missing, and extra volumes.
    • It outputs a metric score based on the selected metric method.
    • It provides histograms showing the distribution of errors by distance.

• The system supports the development of custom metric methods.
    • Users can define formulas using parameters like "mm Forgive" and "mm UpperCutoff."
    • The system displays a graph of the metric method for visualization.
    • Users can adjust parameters and see real-time updates to the metric graph.

• The system can be used for periodic quality assurance and product evaluation.

<summary>
• Related U.S. Patent Applications:
    • Apparatus and Method for Execution of Floating Point Operations, Ser. No. 06/879,337, filed June 27, 1986.
    • Apparatus and Method for Accelerating Floating Point Addition and Subtraction Operations, Ser. No. 07/064,836, filed June 19, 1987.
    • Both applications are assigned to the assignee of the present invention.

• Background of the Invention:
    • The invention relates to data processing systems and floating point operations.
    • Floating point format represents numbers with a fraction and an exponent, enabling a wide range of numerical manipulation.
    • Floating point operations are complex due to fraction alignment and normalization requirements.

• Challenges in Floating Point Operations:
    • Addition and subtraction in floating point format are more time-consuming than in standard formats.
    • Effective subtraction operations involve multiple steps, including exponent difference calculation, fraction alignment, subtraction, normalization, and rounding.
    • The complexity arises from aligning fractions and normalizing results.

• Effective Subtraction Operation:
    • Effective subtraction is divided into two cases based on the absolute difference of exponent arguments (ABS{DELTA(E)}).
    • When ABS{DELTA(E)} > 1, normalization requires at most a one-bit shift, reducing steps.
    • When ABS{DELTA(E)} ≤ 1, fraction alignment and subtraction can be performed simultaneously, reducing execution time.

• Acceleration Techniques:
    • A subset of exponent argument signals (TDELTA(E)) is used to initiate fraction operations before the full exponent difference is calculated.
    • If the full exponent difference (DELTA(E)) differs from the subset, the correct result is one of the operand fractions, which is already available.
    • This approach reduces computation time by overlapping operations.

• Apparatus Implementation:
    • A 7-bit subtraction unit calculates T7DELTA(E), a subset of exponent differences.
    • Shift and selection logic units use T7DELTA(E) to determine fraction operations.
    • Detection logic units select the correct final fraction result based on DELTA(E).

• Final Fraction Calculation:
    • When TDELTA(E) = 0, FRACTION A - FRACTION B is calculated.
    • When TDELTA(E) = 1, FRACTION A - FRACTION B / 2 is calculated.
    • When TDELTA(E) = -1, FRACTION B - FRACTION A / 2 is calculated.

• Error Handling and Correct Results

<summary>

	• The system involves storing unique barcodes for patient ID bands, orders, specimen-takers, and pre-labeled specimen containers in a relational database.  
	• The method ensures that the patient's identity matches the order and specimen container before collecting the specimen, reducing errors.  
	• The system generates alerts if the specimen container is out-of-date or if the specimen collection process exceeds a predetermined time.  
	• The invention eliminates the need for additional vial labels, reducing costs and labor associated with manual labeling.  

• The system is implemented using a computer program that processes and stores barcode data, ensuring a failsafe, zero-defect process for specimen collection.  
	• The computer program verifies the relationship between patient barcodes, order barcodes, and specimen-taker barcodes before allowing specimen collection.  
	• The system uses barcode scanners to input data, ensuring accuracy and reducing human error in the specimen collection process.  
	• The invention can be applied to various types of biological specimens, not limited to blood, as shown in the list of routinely collected specimens.  
	• The system provides a complete record of the specimen collection event, stored in a relational database for easy retrieval and analysis.

	• The device provides verbal feedback on distances and other golf course parameters, and can be integrated into headgear or clothing.  
• The device includes advanced features like bone conductance vibration sensors, Bluetooth connectivity, and the ability to record and analyze golf course data.

<summary>  
* Overview of the Invention  
    * The invention relates to semiconductor design technology, specifically systems and techniques for implementing circuit designs into silicon-based ICs.  
    * It addresses challenges in design rule checking (DRC) for mixed logic and memory circuits in system-on-chip (SOC) designs.  
    * The invention aims to eliminate false errors caused by applying logic rules to memory regions and vice versa.  
    * It provides a method to apply customized design rules to different regions (logic, memory) of an IC layout.  

* Key Features and Methodology  
    * Customized design rules are created by modifying standard logic rules to accommodate memory-specific parameters.  
    * The system categorizes errors into logic, BDSP SRAM, BLSP SRAM, DP SRAM, and ROM regions for accurate reporting.  
    * Memory regions are identified using memory ID layers, allowing the system to apply appropriate rules.  
    * The invention ensures that logic regions comply with logic rules, while memory regions comply with memory rules.  

* Advantages Over Prior Art  
    * Eliminates the need for manual filtering of false errors caused by applying logic rules to memory regions.  
    * Reduces design cycle time by automating error detection and classification.  
    * Improves accuracy by ensuring that each region is checked against its specific design rules.  
    * Can be applied to various memory types (e.g., SRAM, ROM, DRAM) and extended to other industries like LCD manufacturing.  

* Implementation and Results  
    * The system uses a design rule checker to process mask pattern data (e.g., GDS format) and generate error reports.  
    * Customized memory rules are derived by analyzing violations in memory bit cells against standard logic rules.  
    * The results include separate error reports for logic and memory regions, ensuring no false errors are reported.  
    * The invention is implemented using conventional computer systems and software routines, making it adaptable to existing workflows.  
</summary>

<summary>
• Government Support and Patent Information
    • The invention was developed with Government support under contract F300606-88-D-0025 awarded by the Rome Air Development Center, Department of the Air Force.
    • This application is a continuation-in-part of U.S. Patent application Ser. No. 07/790,516, filed Nov. 12, 1991, now abandoned, with its entire disclosure incorporated by reference.

• Field of the Invention
    • The invention pertains to waveguide holograms used as illuminators for objects with specific illumination requirements.
    • It is particularly useful for illuminating display holograms or spatial light modulators (SLMs).

• Background of the Prior Invention
    • The parent application disclosed waveguide holograms based on thin substrate waveguides, characterized by the relationship between the width of the incident laser beam and the waveguide thickness.
    • These waveguides allow for uniform illumination and avoid coupling difficulties, making them suitable for controlled illumination applications.

• Summary of the Invention
    • Thin substrate waveguides provide controlled illumination for objects like holograms and SLMs, with high diffraction efficiency.
    • Non-uniformity in the diffracted wavefront can be compensated using photographic emulsions or by recording the hologram non-uniformly.

• Advantages of Waveguide Hologram (WGH) Illuminators
    • WGHs are compact, rugged, and reduce reflection losses, making them superior to conventional lens systems.
    • They achieve high diffraction efficiency (up to 0.99) and eliminate stray light due to total internal reflection.

• Challenges and Solutions
    • Alignment sensitivity and illumination depletion are challenges, but can be addressed by attaching the light source firmly or using spatially broad sources.
    • Non-uniformity in illumination can be corrected a priori or a posteriori, and two-sided diffraction can be managed using absorbers or mirrors.

• Experimental Configurations
    • Two recording systems were used: a modified conventional holographic recording system and a configuration with a prism coupler for stringent waveguide requirements.
    • Experiments demonstrated the effectiveness of WGHs in illuminating SLMs and generating coherent illumination beams.

• Performance Analysis
    • The quality of reconstructed beams was analyzed, with emphasis on polarization and phase characteristics.
    • A slight non-uniform depolarization was observed, likely due to local strains, and phase distortions were minimized using specific recording configurations.

• Scope of the Invention
    • The invention is not limited to the described embodiments and can be adapted for various light sources and illumination objects

<summary>
• Field of the Invention
    • Relates to testing rotors of dynamoelectric machines.
    • Focuses on squirrel cage rotors for induction motors.
    • Measures resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew.
    • Aims to identify rotor defects non-destructively.

• Background of the Invention
    • Squirrel cage rotors are mass-produced with high uniformity.
    • Potential defects include porosity, impurities, and open circuits.
    • Testing is necessary to maintain quality control.
    • Prior methods are either expensive, destructive, or require operator expertise.

• Objects of the Invention
    • Provide a non-destructive testing method and apparatus.
    • Measure resistance and reactance economically and reliably.
    • Measure effective skew of rotors.
    • Automate pass/fail determinations and statistical evaluations.

• Summary of the Invention
    • Test apparatus includes a test head with exciting and sensing means.
    • Rotor is magnetized and rotated to induce voltages and currents.
    • Voltage, current, and skew signals are processed to determine rotor characteristics.
    • Results are used for pass/fail decisions and statistical analysis.

• Detailed Description of the Apparatus
    • Test head includes primary windings, voltage pick-up coils, and skew pick-up coils.
    • Rotor is rotated within a magnetic field generated by the test head.
    • Data acquisition system samples and processes signals.
    • Results are displayed and stored for statistical analysis.

• Data Acquisition and Processing
    • Sample and hold circuit captures voltage, current, and skew signals.
    • Phase lock loop synchronizes sampling with the excitation current.
    • Data processor calculates resistance, reactance, and skew.
    • Control processor determines pass/fail based on predefined thresholds.

• Test Fixture and Mechanism
    • Dual test fixtures allow efficient testing with minimal operator downtime.
    • Hydraulic retraction and drive mechanism positions and rotates the rotor.
    • Clutch mechanism securely holds the rotor during testing.
    • Position sensors ensure proper alignment and rotation.

• Advantages and Applications
    • Non-destructive testing ensures rotor quality without damage.
    • Automated system reduces operator intervention and training requirements.
    • Statistical data aids in process improvement and quality control.
    • Dual fixture setup increases testing efficiency and cost-effectiveness.
</summary>

<summary>
* Background and Security Challenges in Mobile Devices  
	* Mobile devices are increasingly powerful, enabling sophisticated applications, but require robust security measures to protect against attackers seeking digital rights management (DRM) keys or device keys.  
	* Providers often "close" devices by restricting hardware and software to proprietary systems, but this limits third-party application development, necessitating alternative security techniques.  

* Managed Libraries and Application Security  
	* Managed libraries are granted access to native operating system resources after validating digital certificates, ensuring only trusted code interacts with critical system functions.  
	* Managed applications are denied direct access to native resources but can access specific resources through managed libraries, controlled by a manager that enforces security policies.  

* Verification and Distribution of Applications  
	* Applications are verified for type safety and metadata integrity before being packaged into digitally signed containers, ensuring they meet security standards.  
	* Verified applications are distributed through an electronic marketplace, where they can be purchased and downloaded to mobile devices, with runtime checks ensuring continued security.  
</summary>

<summary>

    * Invention relates to an improved identification card with an internal antenna and IC chip.  
    * Prior art smart cards are rigid, prone to damage, and costly to produce.  
    * Need for a low-cost, durable card that protects electronic components from bending and stress.  

* Structure of the Identification Card  
    * Core layer made of silica-filled polyolefin with antenna and IC chip attached.  
    * Bottom sheet of silica-filled polyolefin bonded to the core layer with adhesive.  
    * Rigid outer laminate layers encase the core and bottom layers for structural support.
